activityinfo.activityTitle: Connecting Area Models and the Distributive Property
activityinfo.subject: MATH
activityinfo.prompt: To rewrite products to formalize the Distributive Property

editors.title: Prepare
editors.editorValue:
Purpose: To rewrite products to formalize the Distributive Property

Driver of Investigation: Make sense of the world.

editors.title: Activity Steps
editors.editorValue:
• Read and discuss the situation.
  • Group students to complete Question 1.
  • Check in and share.
  • Read and discuss the key terms.
  • Group students to complete Question 2.
  • Check in and share.
  • Read and discuss the key term.
  • Group students to complete Question 3.
  • Check in and share.
  • Read and discuss the Worked Example.
  • Group students to complete Questions 4 and 5.
  • Share and summarize: You can use the Distributive Property to rewrite the product of two factors as a factor times the sum of two or more terms.

questions: What is an area model?﻿﻿
How did you take apart the length to obtain specific ﻿values that add up to 27 feet?﻿

Action & Expression: Expression & C﻿ommunication
Students may draw a diagonal line to divide the area. While correct, discuss that their choice makes two trapezoids instead of rectangles, and it is much more efficient to use rectangles. Also, students will need to use rectangles to model the Distributive Property.﻿

Observe students as they complete Question 1.
• Are students decomposing 27 into numbers that make the computation of the area more efficient?
• Are students using the correct dimensions for each of the smaller ﻿regions in the area model?﻿

This is the first pairing of these Habits of Mind:
• Look for and make use of structure.
• Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

﻿Have students refer to Habits of Mind for questions to ask themselves, either in MATHbook (page xix) or digital activity.

Why is using parentheses necessary?

﻿Why is 5 repeated in both parentheses?﻿

How does the sum in the parentheses relate to the area model?

How might dividing the rectangle into three regions change the way you write the corresponding ﻿equation using the Distributive Property?﻿
Which combination of values is the most efficient ﻿one to use?﻿

Help students differentiate between the terms expression and equation.

Have students sha﻿re the similarities and differences between expressions and equations. Then, have them provide additional examples of each.﻿

﻿What does it mean to distribute something?

Explain what is meant by “multiplication over addition.”
Where is multiplication implied in the equation a(b + c) = ab + ac?﻿﻿

Engagement: Sustaining Effort & Persistence
Have students discuss what the equation looks like when they divide the model into more than two regio﻿ns.﻿

Remind students to refer to the Academic Glossary to review the definition of describe and related phrases, either in MATHbook (page xx) or digital activity.﻿

Suggest they ask themselves these questions:
• How should I organize my thoughts?
• Did I consider the context of the situation?

What is the purpose of the arrows in the example?

Draw a diagram to represent this expression.

Could you write the expression as (2 + 15)4? ﻿Explain your thinking.﻿

What is the error in each false statement?

﻿How do you read each true statement?﻿
What is important to keep in mind when you ﻿are distributing a factor over a quantity?﻿
What are the factors in the original equation?﻿﻿

Why did you choose the sum of those two values to represent the factor?

Are some sums a better choice than others? ﻿Explain your thinking.﻿

﻿Representation: Building Knowledge﻿
Demonstrate how the Distributive Property can help with mental math by expressing one factor as the sum of the tens and ones values. For example:
3 × 28 = 3(20 + 8) = 60 + 24 = 84.﻿
